The first tranche of funds for schools in this initiative was issued by my Department in mid-January 2000.

Qst.Quest: the position in relation to the provision of a new primary school in the Grange-Frankfield area of Cork; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: The Office of Public Works which is acting as the agent of my Department in relation to the procurement of sites has been requested to investigate the availability of a site for the school in question.

Qst.Quest: if a resource teacher has been appointed to a school (details supplied) in County Mayo; and, if so, the number of hours per week sanctioned.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: A full-time resource teacher post has been allocated on a shared basis between the school in question and three other schools in the area which are catering for children with special needs. The amount of time which the resource teacher devotes to each school is determined on an ongoing basis by the needs of the individual children involved.

Qst.Quest: the funding, if any, available to assist parents of special needs children in learning teaching methods to enable them assist their children at home, such as a person (details supplied) in County Mayo.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: The needs of pupils such as those referred to by the Deputy are generally capable of being met within the ordinary school system, with the support where necessary, of the remedial or resource teacher service. Both of these services have been significantly expanded in the current school year. The remedial service is now available in all schools with a pupil teacher ratio of 10:1 or more. The resource teacher service is now available on an automatic basis to any child in the primary system who has been assessed as requiring such support.

For some children, the severity of their condition can be such that placement in a special school or in a special class attached to an ordinary school is the required response. At present, there are four such special schools and 16 special classes catering for children with specific learning disability, including dyslexia. All these facilities operate at a reduced pupil teacher ratio of 11:1 and pupils attending these facilities attract an enhanced level of capitation funding.
Children with special needs, including those with dyslexia, can also qualify for funding for special equipment where the need for such support has been established.

My Department does not provide direct funding to individual parents to assist them in learning teaching methods to enable them to assist their children at home. The resources available to my Department are generally targeted towards school based supports for children with special educational needs, including children with dyslexia.

However, in addition to the range of in-school supports made available to children with dyslexia, my Department supports the out of school programmes which the Association for Children and Adults with Learning Disabilities provides for children with dyslexia and their parents. In the current year, my Department is allocating £50,000 to support the work of the association.
I will arrange to have my Department's inspectorate examine the needs of the children to which the Deputy refers to ensure that adequate educational provision is made available to them.

Qst.Quest: the status of an application received by his Department for new additional accommodation or refurbishment required by a school (details supplied) in County Westmeath; when this will be dealt with; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: The long-term staffing and enrolment situation at the school in question is being assessed by my Department and when this process has been completed, further consideration will be given to the accommodation needs of the school.

Qst.Quest: if the second assistant teacher has been retained in a school (details supplied) in County Cork.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: The authorised staffing level for the school in question for the 1999-2000 school year is a principal plus one assistant teacher. The school in question also has the services of a shared remedial teacher and a resource teacher.

The resource teaching post was allocated exclusively to the school in question to enable the school authorities to cater for two pupils with special educational needs. This post will continue to be available to the school while the children in question remain on the school roll.

Qst.Quest: if he will give details regarding the new £10 million college announced by his predecessor for the northside of Cork city with specific details on the faculties to be located there and the location of the college.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: University College Cork – National University of Ireland, Cork, and Cork Institute of Technology have jointly proposed the establishment of a college of higher education on the northside of Cork city. A detailed analysis of this proposal in terms of the scope and scale of the college is being undertaken. Accordingly, the details on the faculties to be located in the college and the location of the college are not yet available.

Qst.Quest: when a person (details supplied) in County Cork will receive a higher education grant.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: The higher education grants scheme has a provision to the effect that, in the case of a candidate other than an independent mature candidate, the candidate's reckonable income shall be that of the candidate and of the candidate's parents or guardians, except where the candidate's parents are divorced, legally separated or it is established to the satisfaction of the local authority that they are separated, in which case the candidate's reckonable income is taken as that of the candidate and of the parent with whom the candidate resides. The other student support schemes have a similar provision.

The case in question is one of a number of cases that have been referred to my Department by local authorities and vocational education committees where the candidate is not living with or being supported by their parents. The question of whose income, if any, should be reckoned for the purpose of deciding whether a candidate is eligible for a higher education grant arises in these cases. My officials are considering the various issues raised in these cases and a report is being prepared for my consideration. I will advise the Deputy of the outcome.

Qst.Quest: if he will sanction an extension to Kilmagner national school, Fermoy, County Cork; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: The application will be dealt with as quickly as possible having regard to the large number of schools building projects on hand within my Department.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Disadvantaged Status.

Qst.Quest: if he will extend disadvantaged status to Portlaw national school, County Waterford; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: I am aware of the case made by the school in question for inclusion in the disadvantaged areas scheme.

The Taoiseach recently launched a major £194 million plan to tackle educational disadvantage at all levels. A key objective of this plan is to ensure that support services for disadvantaged pupils are properly targeted at those most in need.

MainHeading.P: Traditional approaches to addressing the problem of educational disadvantage have lacked the necessary flexibility to target individual and small groups of pupils suffering educational disadvantage. The system has tended to concentrate resources on schools with the highest concentrations of disadvantaged pupils, while failing to give adequate support to other schools with smaller but nonetheless serious pockets of disadvantage.

Under the New Deal – A Plan for Educational Opportunity it is intended that all primary schools, including the school to which the Deputy refers, will be surveyed to identify the precise distribution of disadvantaged pupils across the system. It is intended that this survey will be carried out during the current school term.

In response to the levels of disadvantage identified through the survey, additional supports will be made available to schools to meet the needs of their pupils. The level and nature of the support services made available will vary depending on the level of need identified.

I can assure the Deputy that it is my intention to attach particular priority to the issue of educational disadvantage and to ensure that an efficient and effective system of support for disadvantaged pupils is put in place by my Department.

Qst.Quest: if he will give details in relation to the reduction from eight to seven teachers for the appointment of administrative principals to national schools; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: Administrative principals are currently appointed to primary schools with eight or more mainstream class teachers. Administrative principals will be appointed to all schools with seven mainstream class teachers from the 1 September 2000.
Details regarding the implementation of the proposal and its impact on the staffing schedule are currently being discussed with the partners in education.

Qst.Quest: if, further to parliamentary Question No. 319 of 10 February 1998, he will report on the conditions of the windows at Kilcredan national school, County Cork; if his Department will provide grant aid to replace these windows; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: The application will be dealt with as quickly as possible having regard to the large number of schools building projects on hand within my Department.

Qst.Quest: if, further to parliamentary Question No. 317 of 3 June 1998, the pilot study, which was due to commence in 1998 in order to determine the optimum specifications for a dust extraction system at schools, has taken place; the schools at which this pilot study was undertaken; the results obtained and the general policy decisions he has taken as a result of this study; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: A pilot project is under way at present to analyse the effectiveness of integral dust extraction systems in meeting the needs of second level schools. The evaluation report on this pilot project is expected by the end of April 2000.

The project is being conducted in the following schools: St. McDara's community college, Wellington Lane, Templogue; Killinarden community school, Dublin; Deansrath community college, New Nangor Road, Clondalkin; St. Kevin's community college, Fonthill Road, Clondalkin; Lucan community school; Meanscoil an Clochair, Kilbeggan, County Westmeath; Bishopstown community school, Cork; Douglas community school, Cork; Colaiste an Spiorad Naomh, Bishopstown, Cork; Mayfield community school, Cork; Dunmore community school, County Galway; Davitt College, Castlebar, County Mayo.

Qst.Quest: further to reply to Parliamentary Question No. 267 of 9 June 1998, the plans, if any, he has to extend the special development project organised by his Department's psychological service in the primary sector to other primary schools; if he will include Kilcredan primary school in County Cork in any new scheme; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: The National Educational Psychological Service – NEPS – agency was established on 1 September 1999. The management committee of NEPS is preparing a development plan for the phased expansion of the service to all schools in the country which, it is envisaged, will take five years. The priorities for expansion will be agreed by the management committee in consultation with local interests, including other providers of psychological services. Relevant data about each county, including County Cork, are being collected by NEPS and this will be supplemented by local discussions. I am pleased to inform the Deputy that The Civil Service and Local Appointments Commission is currently in the process of recruiting additional psychologists for NEPS. The process is well advanced and my Department hopes to be in a position to make offers of appointment in the near future.
